causes: Apple scab is caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis. It thrives in cool, wet conditions, spreading through spores carried by wind or rain, and overwinters in infected debris.
remedial_measures: Prune infected branches, improve air circulation, and remove fallen leaves. Apply fungicides preventatively, starting before bud break. Select resistant apple varieties and practice good orchard sanitation.

causes: Black rot, caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa, spreads through infected fruit and leaves, thriving in warm, wet weather. It overwinters in cankers on twigs and branches.
remedial_measures: Remove and destroy infected plant material. Apply fungicides during the growing season and prune to improve air circulation. Practice orchard sanitation to reduce overwintering sites.

causes: Cedar apple rust is caused by the fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae, which requires both apple and cedar trees to complete its life cycle. Spores from cedar infect apple trees in moist conditions.
remedial_measures: Remove nearby cedar trees if possible. Apply fungicides during apple's susceptible growth stages. Prune to improve air circulation and remove infected plant material.

causes: Powdery mildew in cherries is caused by the fungus Podosphaera clandestina. It thrives in warm, dry conditions, spreading through spores carried by wind.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively, starting before symptoms appear. Prune to improve air circulation and remove infected plant parts. Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization.

disease: cercospora leaf spot gray leaf spot
causes: Cercospora leaf spot, caused by the fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis, thrives in warm, humid conditions. It spreads through infected crop residue and debris, as well as wind-driven rain or irrigation water.
remedial_measures: Rotate crops to break disease cycles. Plant resistant corn varieties. Apply fungicides preventatively during periods of high disease pressure. Practice good sanitation by removing and destroying infected plant debris.

causes: Common rust, caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi, spreads through airborne spores in warm, humid conditions. It overwinters on crop residue and alternate hosts.
remedial_measures: Plant resistant corn varieties. Apply fungicides preventatively during the growing season. Practice crop rotation and remove infected debris to reduce overwintering sites.

causes: Northern leaf blight, caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum, thrives in warm, humid conditions. It spreads through wind-dispersed spores and overwinters in crop debris.
remedial_measures: Plant resistant corn hybrids. Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity and leaf wetness. Practice crop rotation and tillage to bury infected residue.

causes: Black rot, caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii, infects grapevines during wet spring weather. Spores spread through rain and wind, and the disease overwinters in infected plant debris.
remedial_measures: Prune grapevines to improve airflow and reduce moisture. Apply fungicides preventatively during the growing season. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Bacterial spot, caused by Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni, infects peach trees through wounds or natural openings during warm, wet weather. It spreads through rain splash and+C10 wind.
remedial_measures: Practice careful pruning to minimize wounds and avoid pruning during wet periods. Apply preventive fungicides to protect healthy tissue. Improve vineyard airflow and drainage to reduce humidity.

causes: Leaf blight, caused by the fungus Isariopsis indica, thrives in warm, humid conditions. It spreads through rain splash and wind, infecting grape leaves and clusters.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Prune grapevines to improve airflow and reduce leaf wetness. Remove and destroy infected plant material.

causes: Huanlongbing, caused by the bacterium Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus, is spread by Asian citrus psyllids. Infected trees show symptoms such as yellowing leaves, stunted growth, and bitter fruit.
remedial_measures: Control psyllid populations with insecticides and biological control methods. Remove and destroy infected trees promptly. Plant certified disease-free citrus trees and monitor orchards regularly.

causes: Bacterial spot, caused by Xanthomonas arboricola pv. pruni, infects peach trees through wounds or natural openings during warm, wet weather. It spreads through rain splash and wind.
remedial_measures: Apply copper-based fungicides preventatively during the growing season. Prune trees to improve airflow and reduce humidity. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Bacterial spot, caused by Xanthomonas spp., spreads through contaminated seeds, plant debris, and splashing water. Warm, humid conditions favor its development.
remedial_measures: Plant disease-free seeds and transplants. Apply copper-based bactericides preventatively and rotate with non-susceptible crops. Remove and destroy infected plants promptly.

causes: Early blight, caused by the fungus Alternaria solani, thrives in warm, humid conditions. It spreads through infected seed potatoes, plant debris, and wind-driven rain.
remedial_measures: Rotate crops with non-solanaceous plants. Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Late blight, caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans, spreads rapidly in cool, moist conditions. It thrives during periods of high humidity and can overwinter in infected tubers.
remedial_measures: Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes. Apply fungicides preventatively and maintain good airflow within the crop canopy. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Powdery mildew, caused by various fungi including Podosphaera xanthii, thrives in warm, dry conditions. It spreads through airborne spores and can overwinter on crop debris.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Plant resistant squash varieties. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Leaf scorch, caused by the fungus Diplocarpon earlianum, spreads through splashing water and infected plant debris. It thrives in warm, humid conditions.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively during periods of high disease pressure. Practice good sanitation by removing and destroying infected leaves and debris. Plant disease-resistant strawberry cultivars.

causes: Bacterial spot, caused by Xanthomonas spp., spreads through contaminated seeds, plant debris, and splashing water. Warm, humid conditions favor its development.
remedial_measures: Plant disease-free seeds and transplants. Apply copper-based bactericides preventatively and rotate with non-susceptible crops. Remove and destroy infected plants promptly.

causes: Early blight, caused by the fungus Alternaria solani, spreads through infected plant debris, contaminated seeds, and wind-driven rain. Warm, humid conditions favor its development.
remedial_measures: Rotate tomato crops with non-solanaceous plants. Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Late blight, caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans, spreads rapidly in cool, moist conditions. It thrives during periods of high humidity and can overwinter in infected plant debris.
remedial_measures: Plant certified disease-free tomato transplants. Apply fungicides preventatively and maintain good airflow within the crop canopy. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Leaf mold, caused by the fungus Fulvia fulva (formerly Cladosporium fulvum), thrives in warm, humid conditions. It spreads through airborne spores and can overwinter on crop debris.
remedial_measures: Provide good ventilation and spacing between tomato plants. Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Remove and destroy infected plant material promptly.

causes: Septoria leaf spot, caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici, spreads through splashing water and infected plant debris. Warm, humid conditions favor its development.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high disease pressure. Practice good sanitation by removing and destroying infected leaves and debris. Rotate tomato crops with non-solanaceous plants.

causes: Two-spotted spider mites, including Tetranychus urticae, thrive in hot, dry conditions. They feed on plant sap, causing stippling and webbing on leaves.
remedial_measures: Apply insecticidal soaps or miticides to control spider mite populations. Maintain adequate humidity levels and avoid over-fertilization, which can exacerbate mite infestations. Remove and destroy heavily infested plants.

causes: Target spot, caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola, spreads through wind-dispersed spores and infected plant debris. Warm, humid conditions favor its development.
remedial_measures: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during periods of high humidity. Practice good sanitation by removing and destroying infected leaves and debris. Rotate tomato crops with non-solanaceous plants.

causes: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus is transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) and affects tomato plants, causing yellowing, curling, and stunting of leaves.
remedial_measures: Use insecticides to control whitefly populations. Plant virus-resistant tomato varieties. Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent further spread.

causes: Tomato mosaic virus is transmitted through contaminated seed, plant debris, and mechanical means. It causes mottling, distortion, and stunting of tomato plants.
remedial_measures: Plant disease-free seeds and transplants. Control aphid and thrips populations, which can spread the virus. Remove and destroy infected plants promptly to prevent virus spread.
